text: ooh hey everyone triple yellow here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new yola album
stand for myself this is a brand new
record from singer songwriter yola this
is her second for the nashville based
label easy eye sound which was founded
by dan auerbach of black keys fame who
also produced this record along with her
first her first lp was an admirable
collection of country and soul cuts that
occasionally blurred the lines between
those two worlds and if you did not get
it the first time it seems like yola and
dan are really intent on making sure
that you get it the second time with
bigger productions stronger songs and
more stunning vocal performances this
thing is probably one of the easiest
positive reviews i've had to give this
year because everything that makes it so
good is so on the surface it's so plain
it's so apparent the chorus is slap the
instrumentation is glamorous it's rich
it's wonderful it's deeply rooted in
some classic soul and country aesthetics
the tracklist has a very direct flow to
it with each song standing pretty well
on its own merits as a single moment but
also collectively focusing on themes of
overcoming adversity surviving uphill
battles togetherness heartbreak plus
yola's singing comes off as more
versatile on this lp2 there's not a
genre she doesn't sound good approaching
here most of the soul cuts on this lp
are an easy a the country songs have a
bolder twang to them this time around
and honestly if yola were to ever do a
full record of this stuff it would rock
the industry dancing away in tears
dabbles in a bit of string kissed disco
then there's something kind of
anachronistic about the chunky beats and
dramatic vocal leads on if i had to do
it all again it's 90s r b vibes fed
through some classic soul
instrumentation break the bow hits the
fast pacing fire and vocal rasp of a
rock and tina turner track and like a
photograph is what you would get if you
took one of these very slow burning
classic girl group songs and just
touched it with a dash of country
instrumentation here and there so yes a
variety of very well done well-employed
classic sounds all over this lp my
biggest issue with it is that
occasionally
with yola touching down on so much
classic and and god-like music there are
some moments of deja vu here and there
like the vocal melody on dancing away in
tears is so close in some respects to
that of al green's let's stay together
i'm
surprised that his team isn't layering
up right now there are some other spots
on the lp like this though maybe not to
as strong a degree then the song like a
photograph for whatever reason the piano
melody on this one resembles that of the
track starlight just a few songs earlier
and it doesn't necessarily come off like
a reprise and as long as i'm complaining
the track now you're here maybe has the
mildest song writing and instrumentation
in the bunch on the record but i still
think the vocal performance on this one
is killer but with those issues out of
the way i think nearly everything else
on this lp is fire the opener barely
alive is a funky laid-back striving
anthem with some amazing core changes
classic sparkling soul instrumentation
yola's voice sounds fantastic over it
lyrically it's a track about living to
die but dying to live the song diamond
studded shoes features some similar
themes though there are some more
systematic critiques on this one
depicting people who are privileged
buying diamond studded shoes with uh the
tax money of poorer people i mean
diamond studded shoes and um you know
military-grade weapon systems but yeah
this whole track is set against a
groovin country rock instrumental it's
great be my friend is another killer
country cut in the bunch great divide is
a classic ballad in 3 4 with a spotlit
vocal graceful instrumentation yola
sounds dramatic as hell on this one the
grey
divide then things continue on this
somewhat dramatic streak from here like
the glamorous starlight which is about a
patient love a love that's always on
your mind can't get it out of your head
then the final leg of this lp features
some of the most peppy and freeing songs
and instrumentals on the entire project
whatever you want is about being done
with the good old boys and living for
yourself instead the very hype break the
bow i mentioned earlier has lyrics that
read like a blissful dream of mangoes
and beaches and sunshine then the
closing tracks stand for myself which is
a country rocker with some roaring
guitars
is is almost like the opposite it's the
mirror narrative of
the opening song at this point we have
yola not just like you know on the verge
of uh death or desperation but she's
like found this new energy new
confidence and in this respect
emotionally it's like the album works in
these these three parts you have that uh
section toward the start where it is
like really fighting for its life you
have that sort of tearful more dramatic
heart broke moment in the middle where
it's kind of going into more of an
introspective pocket and then the last
portion of the record is like hey we're
at the finish line we've made it we're
empowered ah i'm standing for myself
so yes overall i thought this was
a very well performed written and
produced album with just a lot of
classic sounds from front to back there
are points where we hit a few duds in
the track list or there is a severe lack
of originality going on but there is
something novel about the way yola is
combining some of the classic sounds
that she is on this record and i can't
deny even though that this thing isn't
the most novel record i've heard this
year the writing and the performances
are just really that good and are just
really that entertaining feeling a
decent two strong eight on this one tran
position have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review

it's another video that you can check

forever
